terms.definition: The basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms.
Deoxyribonucleic acid, a molecule that carries genetic instructions for development and functioning of living things.
Organelles that generate energy for the cell through cellular respiration.
The process by which plants convert light energy into chemical energy to produce glucose from carbon dioxide and water.
Large molecules composed of amino acids that are essential for the structure, function, and regulation of cells.
A structure of nucleic acids and protein found in the nucleus of most living cells, carrying genetic information.
Proteins that act as biological catalysts, speeding up chemical reactions in living organisms.
A biological membrane that separates the interior of a cell from the external environment.
A variant form of a gene at a particular locus on a chromosome.
The movement of water molecules through a semipermeable membrane from a region of lower solute concentration to higher concentration.
A molecular machine within cells that synthesizes proteins by translating messenger RNA.
An organelle in plant cells where photosynthesis occurs.
The ability of an organism or environment to maintain stability despite changes.
A change in the DNA sequence that can lead to variations in traits.
A type of cell division that reduces the chromosome number by half, producing four gamete cells.
The process of copying a segment of DNA into RNA.
The process by which a protein is synthesized from the information contained in a molecule of messenger RNA.
A network of protein filaments and tubules in the cytoplasm that provides structural support for the cell.
An organelle in the cytoplasm of eukaryotic cells containing degradative enzymes enclosed in a membrane.
An organelle responsible for modifying, sorting, and packaging proteins and lipids for secretion or use within the cell.
A network of membranes within the cytoplasm involved in protein and lipid synthesis.
A type of endoplasmic reticulum that is studded with ribosomes and plays a role in protein synthesis.
A type of endoplasmic reticulum involved in lipid synthesis and detoxification, lacking ribosomes.
A membrane-bound organelle used for storage, especially prominent in plant cells.
A small, circular, double-stranded DNA molecule distinct from a cellâ€™s chromosomal DNA, often found in bacteria.
A method of asexual reproduction in single-celled organisms by which one cell divides into two cells of the same size.
The science of classifying organisms into ordered systems based on characteristics and evolutionary history.
A segment of DNA that contains the instructions for building a specific protein or set of proteins.
The genetic makeup of an organism in terms of the alleles present.
The observable characteristics or traits of an organism resulting from the interaction of its genotype with the environment.
Single-celled prokaryotic organisms that can be found in diverse environments and may be beneficial or pathogenic.
A non-cellular infectious agent composed of genetic material enclosed in a protein coat, requiring a host cell to replicate.
A protein produced by the immune system that binds to specific antigens to neutralize or mark them for destruction.
A substance or molecule that is recognized by the immune system and can trigger an immune response.
A microorganism or agent, such as a virus, bacterium, or fungus, that causes disease.
A chemical modification of DNA that can affect gene expression without changing the DNA sequence.
Hollow protein tubes that are part of the cytoskeleton, involved in maintaining cell shape, intracellular transport, and cell division.
A protein that forms microfilaments, which are part of the cytoskeleton and play a role in cell movement and shape.
A protein-pigment complex in chloroplasts that captures light energy for photosynthesis.
A series of protein complexes that transfer electrons through a membrane to generate ATP during cellular respiration or photosynthesis.
A process by which cells degrade and recycle their own components through lysosomes.
The metabolic pathway that converts glucose into pyruvate, producing ATP and NADH in the process.
Proteins that span across the cell membrane and assist in transporting molecules and signaling.
A molecule that binds specifically to a receptor site on a protein, often to trigger a biological response.
The process by which a chemical or physical signal is transmitted through a cell as a series of molecular events.
The complete set of genetic material in an organism, including all of its genes and non-coding sequences.
A chemical modification of DNA that affects gene expression without altering the DNA sequence.
Proteins that package and order DNA into structural units called nucleosomes in the nucleus.
The process in which cells lose water in a hypertonic solution, causing the cell membrane to shrink away from the cell wall.
A solution with a higher concentration of solutes compared to another solution, causing water to move out of cells.
A solution with a lower concentration of solutes compared to another solution, causing water to move into cells.
A membrane protein that facilitates the transport of water molecules across cell membranes.
An organism that produces its own food from inorganic substances using light or chemical energy.
An organism that obtains its food and energy by consuming other organisms.
An organism that feeds on other organisms in a food chain.
Organisms that break down dead or decaying organisms, recycling nutrients back into the ecosystem.
A kingdom of usually multicellular organisms that absorb nutrients from organic material, including molds, yeast, and mushrooms.
The network of fine white filaments (hyphae) that forms the main body of a fungus.
The thread-like structures that make up the mycelium of a fungus.
Reproductive cells capable of developing into a new individual without fusion with another cell.
The variety and variability of life forms within a given ecosystem, biome, or the entire Earth.
A community of living organisms interacting with each other and their physical environment.
The natural environment where an organism lives and grows.
The role or function of an organism or species within an ecosystem, including its use of resources and relationships with other organisms.
A group of individuals of the same species living in a specific geographic area at the same time.
An assemblage of different populations of organisms living and interacting in a particular area.
The complete set of different genes and alleles present in a population.
A change in the frequency of alleles in a population due to random sampling effects.
The process by which organisms better adapted to their environment tend to survive and produce more offspring.
The change in the heritable characteristics of biological populations over successive generations.
The evolutionary process by which populations evolve to become distinct species.
The separation of populations so that they no longer interbreed, leading to speciation.
The transfer of genetic material between populations of the same species.
The relative frequency of an allele at a particular locus in a population, expressed as a proportion or percentage.
A biological process where the output of a system influences its own activity, maintaining stability through negative or positive feedback.
A process ensuring that only one allele of a gene is expressed while the other is silenced in diploid organisms.
The biological membrane that separates the interior of all cells from the outside environment, regulating substance passage.
The process of generating ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphate using the energy of sunlight during photosynthesis.
The process by which information from a gene is used to synthesize functional gene products like proteins or RNA.
The study of changes in gene activity that do not involve alterations to the DNA sequence but affect gene expression.
A complex of DNA and proteins found in the nucleus, which packages DNA into a more compact form.
The process by which cells internalize molecules and particles by engulfing them in a vesicle.
The process by which cells expel materials in vesicles that fuse with the plasma membrane.
Long, whip-like structures used by some cells for movement.
Short, hair-like structures on the surface of some cells that aid in movement or sensing the environment.
The process by which genetic material is rearranged during meiosis, leading to new gene combinations.
The exchange of genetic material between homologous chromosomes during meiosis.
A cell that displays foreign antigens complexed with major histocompatibility complexes on its surface to T-cells.
A type of lymphocyte that plays a central role in cell-mediated immunity.
A type of lymphocyte responsible for producing antibodies as part of the adaptive immune response.
Channels between plant cell walls that allow transport and communication between cells.
A protein molecule that receives and responds to a chemical signal.
The division of the cytoplasm of a parental cell into two daughter cells after mitosis or meiosis.
A protein structure on chromatids where spindle fibers attach during cell division to pull sister chromatids apart.
Microtubules that form during cell division and are responsible for separating chromosomes.
The ability of an organism or cell to maintain a stable internal environment despite changes in external conditions.
A biological mechanism in which the output of a process influences the operation of the process itself, either enhancing (positive) or inhibiting (negative) it.
The process of copying a segment of DNA into RNA, especially mRNA, by the enzyme RNA polymerase.
The process by which the sequence of a messenger RNA (mRNA) is used to build a corresponding protein.
A cluster of genes under the control of a single promoter and regulated together, commonly found in prokaryotes.
A well-studied operon in E. coli that controls the metabolism of lactose, often used to illustrate gene regulation.
The intermediate formed when an enzyme binds to its substrate during a biochemical reaction.
The region on an enzyme where the substrate binds and the chemical reaction occurs.
The specific reactant that an enzyme acts upon during a biochemical reaction.
A type of endocytosis in which a cell engulfs large particles or even whole cells.
A cellular process in which substances are brought into the cell by engulfing them in a vesicle.
A type of endocytosis where a cell ingests extracellular fluid and its dissolved solutes.
A process by which a cell transports secretory products through the cytoplasm to the plasma membrane for release.
The division of the cytoplasm to form two separate daughter cells after mitosis or meiosis.
A shallow groove in the cell surface near the old metaphase plate of an animal cell undergoing cytokinesis.
A structure that forms in plant cells during cytokinesis and eventually develops into a separating cell wall.
The complex of DNA and proteins that forms chromosomes within the nucleus of eukaryotic cells.
A type of protein found in cell nuclei that packages and orders DNA into structural units called nucleosomes.
The fundamental unit of chromatin, consisting of a segment of DNA wound around a core of histone proteins.
A small, circular piece of DNA that is separate from chromosomal DNA and can replicate independently, often found in bacteria.
A DNA sequence that can change its position within the genome, sometimes creating mutations and altering the cell's genome size.
The study of changes in gene expression caused by mechanisms other than changes in the DNA sequence.
A segment of DNA to which a repressor binds, thereby regulating the expression of one or more genes.
A functioning unit of genomic DNA containing a cluster of genes under the control of a single promoter.
A well-known operon in bacteria that controls the metabolism of lactose.
A class of proteins involved in electron transport and energy production in mitochondria and chloroplasts.
A microbial process by which ammonia is converted into nitrate, essential for nitrogen cycling in ecosystems.
A microbial process that converts nitrate to nitrogen gas, returning nitrogen to the atmosphere.
A viral reproductive cycle in which a virus enters a host cell, replicates, and causes the cell to burst.
A viral reproductive cycle where the viral DNA is integrated into the host genome and replicated with it without causing immediate lysis.
An enzyme that adds repetitive sequences to the ends of chromosomes, maintaining telomere length and genome stability.
The protective cap at the end of a chromosome that prevents it from deterioration or fusion with neighboring chromosomes.
A broad category of small proteins important in cell signaling, especially in immune responses.
A type of cytokine that mediates communication between immune cells and regulates immune responses.
Chemical messengers that transmit signals across a synapse from one neuron to another.
The junction between two neurons where neurotransmitters are released to transmit signals.
The long, thread-like part of a neuron that transmits impulses away from the cell body.
Branched extensions of a neuron that receive signals from other neurons.
A specialized cell transmitting nerve impulses; the basic unit of the nervous system.
A fatty layer that surrounds the axon of some neurons and increases the speed of impulse transmission.
The metabolic pathway that breaks down glucose into pyruvate, producing ATP and NADH in the process.
A series of chemical reactions used by all aerobic organisms to generate energy through the oxidation of acetate.
A series of proteins in the inner mitochondrial membrane that transfer electrons and produce ATP.
An anaerobic process that allows glycolysis to continue by regenerating NAD+, producing lactic acid or ethanol.
A byproduct of anaerobic respiration in animal cells, especially during intense exercise.
A form of anaerobic respiration where glucose is converted to ethanol and carbon dioxide.
The process by which green plants and some organisms use sunlight to synthesize food from carbon dioxide and water.
An organelle in plant cells that contains chlorophyll and where photosynthesis takes place.
The green pigment in plants that absorbs light energy used to carry out photosynthesis.
The fluid-filled space surrounding the grana in chloroplasts where the Calvin Cycle occurs.
A set of chemical reactions that take place in chloroplasts during photosynthesis, converting carbon dioxide into glucose.
An organism that produces its own food from inorganic substances, using light or chemical energy.
An organism that obtains food by consuming other organisms, unable to produce its own food.
An anaerobic process that produces energy by breaking down glucose without oxygen, resulting in products like lactic acid or ethanol.
A protein-pigment complex in chloroplasts that captures light energy for photosynthesis.
Long, whip-like structures that enable cell movement in some bacteria and eukaryotic cells.
Short hair-like structures on the surface of some cells that aid in movement or sensory functions.
A selectively permeable membrane that surrounds the cell, controlling entry and exit of substances.
The process by which cells engulf external substances, enclosing them in a vesicle for internalization.
The process where cells expel materials by fusing vesicles with the plasma membrane.
